citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Records of animal deaths and necropsy reports since the last inspection on 12/11/2024 showed the death of 14 animals
that were not under direct veterinary care and the death or euthanasia of 2 animals under veterinary care. The following
deaths with dates of the death were reported: 1 dead muntjacs (12/30/24), 1—13 year old fallow deer (1/16/25), 4
chickens (1/16/25, 1/16/25, 2/25/25, & 2/26/25),1 duck (1/19/25), 2 parakeets (1/28/25 & 2/22/25), 2 lovebirds (2/1/25 &
2/10/25), and 3 cockatiels (2/2/25, 2/2/25 & 2/23/25). In addition, 1—9 year old fallow deer died on 1/20/25 while under
veterinary care and 1—7 year old alpaca was euthanized on 1/29/25 while under veterinary care. The primary common
necropsy report findings for the 2 chickens that died on 1/16/25, the fallow deer that died on 1/16/25, the fallow deer that
died on 1/20/25, and the alpaca that was euthanized on 1/29/25 were severe loss of body fat from negative energy
balance. In addition, the pathology report for the fallow deer that died on 1/16/25 described severe dental disease. The
cause of death for the cockatiel that died on 2/23/25 was proposed by staff to be injury or old age. The cause of death of
the remaining 10 animals was unexplained.
The health and well-being of 16 animals over an approximately 3-month period was adversely impacted by inadequate
daily observations and communication with the attending veterinarian. Even the two animals that died under veterinary
care had clearly not been consuming adequate nutrients for a significant length of time. The two chickens that died in
February were observed to be ill and were separated, but the attending veterinarian was not contacted. The remaining 12
animals that died were reported as dead with no reported observations of the animal being ill. This indicates there is not a
robust program in place to identify animal health, husbandry, and/or facility problems and prevent unnecessary and
unattended deaths.
The facility must establish and maintain a program of veterinary care that includes daily observation of all animals to
assess their health and well-being. Further, there must be a mechanism of direct and frequent communication with the
attending veterinarian, so that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health and well-being is conveyed to
the attending veterinarian.

At the time of inspection, no records of acquisition were available for three chickens acquired sometime after the previous
routine inspection was conducted on 12/11/2024.
Appropriate documentation of acquired regulated animals is essential for proper identification and necessary to track
animals used in regulated activities to ensure their humane care, use, and disposition.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records of acquisition and disposition that fully and correctly disclose
required information for all regulated animals, including animals born on the premises.
To be corrected from this day (3/5/2025) forward.

At the time of the inspection, facility personnel acknowledged that they sometimes find the public has placed food and
other items like bags in the petting zoo enclosure (which currently houses domestic goats, domestic pigs, a llama,
domestic ducks, domestic chickens, and peacocks). Further, recent necropsy reports for 2 fallow deer and an alpaca (all
died in January 2025), previously housed in the petting zoo primary enclosure, described the presence of foreign material
(plastic bags, fabric, rope like material, and a rubbery balloon) in the rumen of these animals. The petting zoo primary
enclosure is accessible to the public 24 hours a day with no additional barriers or other means to limit public access.
Failure to provide sufficient distance or barriers between animals and the public increases the risk of injury to both the
animals and the public.
During public exhibition, animals must be handled so there is minimal risk of harm to the animal and to the public, with
sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and the general viewing public to assure the safety of animals and
the public.
To be correct by 04/04/2025.

Some of the woodwork that makes up the inside of the bay window, which is part of the enclosure housing 4 hybrid
Amazon parrots, is in a deteriorated condition and appears to have been damaged by the birds. The wood that makes up
the base and right side jamb of the left part of the bay window has a rough splintered appearance. In addition, the inside
edge of the board that forms the base of the bay window has a roughened appearance.
Damaged wooden surfaces cannot be readily cleaned and sanitized and may present a hazard to the health and well-
being of the birds.
Primary enclosures must be kept in good repair and must be constructed and maintained to ensure that all surfaces in
contact with the birds can be readily cleaned and sanitized or replaced when worn or soiled.
To be corrected from this day (3/5/2025) forward.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, the Environment Enhancement Plan for birds was incomplete. It had been reviewed by the
attending veterinarian who provided comments for changes. However, the Environment Enhancement Plan had not yet
been approved by the attending veterinarian. In addition, the Environment Enhancement Plan did not provide for the
environmental enhancement of the following birds present at the facility: domestic chickens, domestic ducks, Muscovy
ducks, mandarin ducks, domestic turkeys, peacocks, domestic pigeons, golden pheasants, chukars.
Without a documented enrichment plan that address the unique needs of all the birds at the facility and that is
implemented under the direction of the attending veterinarian, birds are at risk of stress, discomfort, and the development
of harmful behaviors.
Facility personnel must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement, adequate to
promote the psychological well-being of the birds at the facility. The plan must be in accordance with currently accepted
professional standards, must be in accordance with the avian regulations, and must be approved by the attending
veterinarian.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
